li: PHP
Login to the web site. Authenticate as a user to the web application.
Verify that SSL is enabled. Use the web browser to check if SSL is enabled.
Examine the session cookie. Examine the cookies stored on the browser. Find the session cookie. Verify that it has the "secure" and "HTTPOnly" flags set.
Verify that session IDs are not disclosed. Examine logs, error messages, and hyperlinks to make sure that session IDs are not disclosed in them.
Store session IDs in cookies. This is the default behavior in PHP.

Enable SSL. SSL has to be enabled to protect session cookies from eavesdropping attacks. Please, refer to the documentation for your web platform for information about enabling and configuring SSL on your web server.

Set the "secure" flag on session cookies. Edit the php.ini file and configure the "session.cookie_secure" setting, like this:
          session.cookie_secure = On

Set the "HTTPOnly" flag on session cookies. Edit the php.ini file and configure the "session.cookie_httponly" setting, like this:
            session.cookie_httponly = On
Do not disclose session IDs. Make sure that session IDs are not disclosed in URLs, logs, or error messages. Do not allow URL rewriting of session cookies.

html:
Applies to

  • PHP

What to Check For

Verify that session IDs are protected by being sent only over SSL, having security flags set, and not being disclosed in URLs or error messages.

Why

Protecting session IDs helps protect user sessions from being hijacked.

How to Check

To verify that session IDs are protected:

  1. Login to the web site. Authenticate as a user to the web application.

  2. Verify that SSL is enabled. Use the web browser to check if SSL is enabled.

  3. Examine the session cookie. Examine the cookies stored on the browser. Find the session cookie. Verify that it has the "secure" and "HTTPOnly" flags set.

  4. Verify that session IDs are not disclosed. Examine logs, error messages, and hyperlinks to make sure that session IDs are not disclosed in them.

How to Fix

To protect session IDs:

  1. Store session IDs in cookies. This is the default behavior in PHP.

  2. Enable SSL. SSL has to be enabled to protect session cookies from eavesdropping attacks. Please, refer to the documentation for your web platform for information about enabling and configuring SSL on your web server.

  3. Set the "secure" flag on session cookies. Edit the php.ini file and configure the "session.cookie_secure" setting, like this:

    session.cookie_secure = On

  4. Set the "HTTPOnly" flag on session cookies. Edit the php.ini file and configure the "session.cookie_httponly" setting, like this:

    session.cookie_httponly = On

  5. Do not disclose session IDs. Make sure that session IDs are not disclosed in URLs, logs, or error messages. Do not allow URL rewriting of session cookies.

Secure Session Management Guidelines

  • Protect Session IDs
  • Use PHP Session Management
  • Use Strong Session IDs
  • Change Session IDs During Authentication
  • Make Inactive Sessions Time-out
  • Make Sessions Time-out
  • Destroy Sessions When Users Log Out
  • Place Logout Links on All Pages That Require Authentication
  • Set the Domain and Path Values on Sessions Cookies
  • Set the HTTPOnly Flag on Session Cookies
  • Set the Secure Flag on Session Cookies

Secure Session Management Checklists

  • Session IDs Are Protected
  • PHP Session Management Is Used
  • Strong Session IDs Are Used
  • Session IDs Are Changed During Authentication
  • Inactive Sessions Time-out
  • Sessions Have an Absolute Time-out
  • Sessions Are Destroyed When Users Log Out
  • All Pages that Use Authentication Have Logout Links
  • The Domain and Path Values of Session Cookies Are Strict
  • The HTTPOnly Flag Is Set on Session Cookies
  • The Secure Flag Is Set on Session Cookies
